awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Postdoctoral Fellowship in Law and Health

Abstract:

This project will support a postdoctoral fellow who will conduct research under the mentorship of senior scholars of law, gender, and health at the University of Michigan. Concerted field-building efforts over the last few years have resulted in a promising set of theoretical tools and methods for approaching the scientific study of relationships between law and health. The postdoctoral fellow's research program will advance scientific understandings by bringing theoretical depth to the study of the intersections of law and health.

This project will nurture a post-doctoral scholar to be housed at the Institute for Research on Women and Gender at the University of Michigan. The postdoctoral fellow will spend two years at the University of Michigan performing research in gender, law, and health using interdisciplinary methods such as interviewing, statistical analysis, and participant observation. The postdoctoral fellow will receive consistent and ongoing mentorship from a team of scholars with established research records in the area of the fellow's work. The goals of the project are for the postdoctoral fellow to advance an excellent research agenda, to publish articles on law and health in peer reviewed journals, to hone grant writing skills, to establish relationships nationally with scholars in the field, and to envision and execute a long-term vision of the fellow's research trajectory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Katharine McCabe completed a Postdoctoral Fellowship in Law and Health at the University of Michigan, Institute for Research on Women and Gender under the supervision of Professors Sandra Levitsky and Anna Kirkland. Dr. McCabe researched how doctors work with their pregnant patients who use drugs or who are suspected of using drugs during their pregnancy. She conducted observations and interviews in different cities in the U.S. (Chicago and Cincinnati) that have different rules for reporting substance use by pregnant women. Research has found that these laws tend to drive people away from prenatal care and criminalize them, which does not help their substance use problem and endangers their health and their relationship to their pregnancy and/or child. Dr. McCabe found that doctors are deeply intertwined with law enforcement and social welfare systems under these laws as they provide prenatal care, and that they are often serving in a legal role (but with no protections for the person they are investigating, their patient) that they are reluctant to acknowledge. Dr. McCabe has published her findings in peer-reviewed journals and won an award for one of her pieces, “Criminalization of Care: Drug Testing Pregnant Patients," published in 2022 in the Journal of Health and Social Behavior. She also studied the relationship between substance use in pregnancy and subsequent child abuse. Dr. McCabe also collaborated with a team of Family Medicine clinicians and residents at Michigan Medicine on a project examining racial disparities in newborn drug screening. The team has presented the results at the Diversity in Medicine Conference and North American Primary Care Research Group conference. The results are being prepared for peer-review in the Journal of American Medical Association (JAMA). Dr. McCabe is working on a book manuscript, Punishing Dependency: Policing Gendered Poverty through Health in the Twenty First Century, which will be a major contribution to the sociology of medicine and law and a defining work on reproduction and drug use in the opioid era.
